# Cambridge International AS & A Level  

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[92, 170, 194, 201]]<|/det|>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[92, 221, 170, 250]]<|/det|>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[620, 220, 720, 250]]<|/det|>
CANDIDATE NUMBER  

<|ref|>image<|/ref|><|det|>[[737, 214, 905, 255]]<|/det|>  

<|ref|>sub_title<|/ref|><|det|>[[92, 276, 230, 292]]<|/det|>
## MATHEMATICS  

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[92, 301, 240, 316]]<|/det|>
Paper 4 Mechanics  

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[780, 277, 905, 293]]<|/det|>
9709/41  

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[780, 302, 905, 317]]<|/det|>
May/June 2024  

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[760, 326, 905, 342]]<|/det|>
1 hour 15 minutes  

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[92, 355, 393, 371]]<|/det|>
You must answer on the question paper.  

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[92, 384, 392, 400]]<|/det|>
You will need: List of formulae (MF19)  

<|ref|>sub_title<|/ref|><|det|>[[92, 418, 222, 434]]<|/det|>
## INSTRUCTIONS  

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[92, 435, 275, 450]]<|/det|>
Answer all questions.  

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[92, 450, 760, 466]]<|/det|>
Use a black or dark blue pen. You may use an HB pencil for any diagrams or graphs.  

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[92, 466, 806, 482]]<|/det|>
Write your name, centre number and candidate number in the boxes at the top of the page.  

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[92, 482, 562, 497]]<|/det|>
Write your answer to each question in the space provided.  

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[92, 498, 480, 512]]<|/det|>
Do not use an erasable pen or correction fluid.  

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[92, 513, 354, 527]]<|/det|>
Do not write on any bar codes.  

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[92, 528, 868, 559]]<|/det|>
If additional space is needed, you should use the lined page at the end of this booklet; the question number or numbers must be clearly shown.  

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[92, 560, 480, 574]]<|/det|>
You should use a calculator where appropriate.  

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[92, 575, 880, 605]]<|/det|>
You must show all necessary working clearly; no marks will be given for unsupported answers from a calculator.  

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[92, 606, 856, 636]]<|/det|>
Give non- exact numerical answers correct to 3 significant figures, or 1 decimal place for angles in degrees, unless a different level of accuracy is specified in the question.  

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[92, 636, 777, 652]]<|/det|>
Where a numerical value for the acceleration due to gravity \((g)\) is needed, use \(10 \text{m} \text{s}^{- 2}\) .  

<|ref|>sub_title<|/ref|><|det|>[[92, 681, 213, 695]]<|/det|>
## INFORMATION  

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[92, 697, 384, 712]]<|/det|>
The total mark for this paper is 50.  

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[92, 712, 728, 728]]<|/det|>
The number of marks for each question or part question is shown in brackets [ ].

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[79, 75, 96, 92]]<|/det|>
<label>1</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 75, 920, 109]]<|/det|>
A car starts from rest and accelerates at \(2 \mathrm{m s}^{-2}\) for \(10 \mathrm{s}\). It then travels at a constant speed for \(30 \mathrm{s}\). The car then uniformly decelerates to rest over a period of \(20 \mathrm{s}\).

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 122, 146, 140]]<|/det|>
<label>(a)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[154, 122, 581, 140]]<|/det|>
Sketch a velocity-time graph for the motion of the car.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[890, 122, 920, 140]]<|/det|>
<mark>[2]

<|ref|>image<|/ref|><|det|>[[237, 149, 761, 415]]<|/det|>


<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[114, 490, 148, 510]]<|/det|>
<label>(b)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[154, 490, 490, 510]]<|/det|>
Find the total distance travelled by the car.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[890, 490, 920, 510]]<|/det|>
<mark>[2]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[77, 72, 92, 89]]<|/det|>
<label>2</label>

<|ref|>image<|/ref|><|det|>[[339, 88, 638, 285]]<|/det|>


<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[118, 303, 858, 322]]<|/det|>
Two forces of magnitudes \(20 \text{N}\) and \(F \text{N}\) act at a point \(P\) in the directions shown in the diagram.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[114, 335, 144, 353]]<|/det|>
<label>(a)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[154, 335, 868, 353]]<|/det|>
Given that the resultant force has no component in the \(y\)-direction, calculate the value of \(F\).

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[888, 335, 917, 353]]<|/det|>
<mark>[2]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[114, 551, 144, 570]]<|/det|>
<label>(b)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[154, 551, 798, 570]]<|/det|>
Given instead that \(F = 10\), find the magnitude and direction of the resultant force.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[888, 551, 917, 570]]<|/det|>
<mark>[5]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[77, 73, 94, 89]]<|/det|>
<label>3</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 72, 920, 121]]<|/det|>
A train of mass \(180000\mathrm{kg}\) ascends a straight hill of length \(1.5\mathrm{km}\), inclined at an angle of \(1.5^{\circ}\) to the horizontal. As it ascends the hill, the total work done to overcome the resistance to motion is \(12 000\mathrm{kJ}\) and the speed of the train decreases from \(45\mathrm{m s}^{-1}\) to \(40\mathrm{m s}^{-1}\).

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 133, 838, 152]]<|/det|>
Find the work done by the engine of the train as it ascends the hill, giving your answer in kJ.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[888, 133, 920, 152]]<|/det|>
<mark>[4]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[77, 72, 94, 88]]<|/det|>
<label>4</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 72, 920, 135]]<|/det|>
A car of mass \(1700\mathrm{kg}\) is pulling a trailer of mass \(300\mathrm{kg}\) along a straight horizontal road. The car and trailer are connected by a light inextensible cable which is parallel to the road. There are constant resistances to motion of \(400\mathrm{N}\) on the car and \(150\mathrm{N}\) on the trailer. The power of the car's engine is \(14000\mathrm{W}\).

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 149, 798, 168]]<|/det|>
Find the acceleration of the car and the tension in the cable when the speed is \(20\mathrm{m}\mathrm{s}^{-1}\).

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[890, 149, 920, 168]]<|/det|>
<mark>[6]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[76, 73, 92, 91]]<|/det|>
<label>5</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 72, 920, 107]]<|/det|>
A straight slope of length \(60\mathrm{m}\) is inclined at an angle of \(12^{\circ}\) to the horizontal. A bobsled starts at the top of the slope with a speed of \(5\mathrm{m}\mathrm{s}^{- 1}\) . The bobsled slides directly down the slope.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[114, 119, 144, 136]]<|/det|>
<label>(a)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[154, 117, 628, 136]]<|/det|>
It is given that there is no resistance to the bobsled's motion.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[154, 149, 581, 168]]<|/det|>
Find its speed when it reaches the bottom of the slope.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[890, 149, 920, 168]]<|/det|>
<mark>[3]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[114, 72, 146, 88]]<|/det|>
<label>(b)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[153, 72, 866, 89]]<|/det|>
It is given instead that the coefficient of friction between the bobsled and the slope is 0.03 .

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[153, 102, 732, 120]]<|/det|>
Find the time that it takes for the bobsled to reach the bottom of the slope.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[890, 102, 918, 120]]<|/det|>
<mark>[5]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[76, 72, 96, 89]]<|/det|>
<label>6</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 71, 920, 127]]<|/det|>
A particle moves in a straight line, starting from a point \(O\). The velocity of the particle at time \(t\) s after leaving \(O\) is \(v \mathrm{m} \mathrm{s}^{- 1}\). It is given that \(v = kt^{\frac{1}{2}} - 2t - 8\), where \(k\) is a positive constant. The maximum velocity of the particle is \(4.5 \mathrm{m} \mathrm{s}^{- 1}\).

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 139, 146, 157]]<|/det|>
<label>(a)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[154, 138, 304, 157]]<|/det|>
Show that \(k = 10\).

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[890, 139, 920, 157]]<|/det|>
<mark>[5]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[77, 75, 97, 94]]<|/det|>
<label>7</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 75, 920, 96]]<|/det|>
A particle \(P\) of mass \(0.2 \mathrm{kg}\) is projected vertically upwards from horizontal ground with speed \(25 \mathrm{m s}^{-1}\).

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[114, 107, 144, 126]]<|/det|>
<label>(a)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[154, 106, 751, 126]]<|/det|>
Show that the speed of \(P\) when it reaches \(20 \text{m}\) above the ground is \(15 \text{m s}^{-1}\).

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[890, 107, 920, 126]]<|/det|>
<mark>[2]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[154, 448, 920, 483]]<|/det|>
When \(P\) reaches \(20 \text{m}\) above the ground it collides with a second particle \(Q\) of mass \(0.1 \text{kg}\) which is moving downwards at \(20 \text{m s}^{-1}\). \(P\) is brought to instantaneous rest in the collision.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[114, 494, 144, 512]]<|/det|>
<label>(b)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[154, 494, 579, 512]]<|/det|>
Find the velocity of \(Q\) immediately after the collision.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[890, 494, 920, 512]]<|/det|>
<mark>[2]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 71, 920, 104]]<|/det|>
When \(P\) reaches the ground it rebounds back directly upwards with half of the speed that it had immediately before hitting the ground.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[114, 119, 144, 136]]<|/det|>
<label>(c)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[154, 119, 655, 136]]<|/det|>
Find the height above the ground at which \(P\) and \(Q\) next collide.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[890, 119, 920, 136]]<|/det|>
<mark>[6]

<|ref|>sub_title<|/ref|><|det|>[[432, 72, 567, 89]]<|/det|>
